div.p: A Burning Feaver is diſcharged by the contingency of a Rigor, or exceeding cold ſupervening.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 63.
div.p: Feavers which have daily rigors, are every day diſſolved.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 17.
div.p: The frequent uſe of cold things, cauſeth convulſions, diſtenſions of the nerves, blackneſſe, and feaveriſh rigors.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 20.
div.p: Cold things cauſe a gnawing in ulcers, hardens the skin, hinders from ſuppuration, cauſeth blackneſſe, Feaveriſh rigors, convulſions and diſtenſions of the nerves.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of Convulſions in Feavers.
Sect. 2. Aph. 26.
div.p: IT is better that a Feaver ſhould come upon a Convulſion, then a Convulſion upon a Feaver.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 57.
div.p: A Succeeding Feaver frees him that is taken with a Convulſion, or the cramp.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 66.
div.p: Convulſions and vehement pains happening about the bowels in acute Feavers preſage ill.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 67.
div.p: Tremblings and Convulſions happening to Feaveriſh perſons in their ſleeps, are bad.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 68.
div.p: Interception of ſpirits in Feavers is naught, for it is an argument of a Convulſion.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 5.
div.p: If a drunken perſon be ſuddenly Speechleſſe, he dyes convulſive, unleſſe a Feaver ſucceed, or he recovering his Speech the ſame hour that the humour is uſually digeſted.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 70.
div.p: Thoſe who have Quartane Feavers, are ſeldome taken with Convulſions, but if they are firſt taken a ſucceeding Feavers frees them.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the reſt of the Symptomes happening in Feavers.
Sect. 4. Aph. 27.
div.p: THey which have loſt much blood by Feavers, from what part ſoever the ſlux was, have ſoluble bodies when they are refreſhed, or have recovered their ſtrength.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 31.
div.p: They which have a ſenſe of Lazineſſe or indiſpoſition cauſed by Feavers, have tumors about their joynts, and chiefly about their mandibles or jawbones.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 34.
div.p: A ſuddain ſtrangulation happening in a Feaver without any preceeding tumour in the jaws, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 35.
div.p: If the neck be perverted on a ſuddain, ſo that the Sick can hardly ſwallow, and if no tumor do appear, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 44.
div.p: Tumours or pains about the joynts, do accompany thoſe who have had long Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 44.
div.p: Extremity of cold in the external parts, and burning heats in the internal, with a vehement thirſt, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 49.
div.p: In continual Feavers, if the Lip, Eye-lid, Eye, or Noſe, be turned aſide, if the Sick ſee not, neither hear, and be very weak; which ſoever of theſe Signs happen, argue death approaching.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 50.
div.p: Difficulty of breathing, and raving happening in a Feaver which hath no intermiſſion, is deadly.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 51.
div.p: If Intermittent Feavers are not diſſolved by few Criſes at the beginning, they argue the length and continuance of the Diſeaſe.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 52.
div.p: Voluntary tears argue no inconvenience to the Sick either in Feavers, or other Diſeaſes; but tears falling unwillingly, are more inconvenient.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 53.
div.p: Thoſe Feavers are moſt vehement by which a clammy or gluttinous humour doth grow to the Teeth.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 54.
div.p: They which have dry Coughs, lightly provoking, if they continue long in burning Feavers, are not much troubled with thirſt.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 55.
div.p: All Feavers proceeding from the Inflamation of the Glandules or Kernels are bad but Diaries.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 60.
div.p: An Hemorrhagia or bleeding at the Noſe, or a Diarrhaea or Flux of the belly, doth take away deafneſſe cauſed by Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 62.
div.p: It is not good if the Yellow Jaundies appear, in Feaver-ſick perſons, before the ſeventh day.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 63.
div.p: Daily Feavers are diſſolved daily by Rigors.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 64.
div.p: The Jaundies coming upon a Feaver is good if they appear upon the ſeventh, ninth, eleventh, or fourteenth day; unleſſe the right Hypocondrium be hard, then it is not good.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 65.
div.p: A vehement heat about the Stomach, and a gnawing in the mouth of the Stomach in Feavers is not good.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 69.
div.p:
Thoſe Urines in Feavers are advantagious, which being thick, curdled, and few, do turn to
thin and many, eſpecially if they be ſuch as have a Sediment at the firſt, or not much after.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 70.
div.p: Urines very much troubled, like thoſe of kine, do ſignifie a pain of the head either preſent, or ſuddenly to ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 73.
div.p: They which have a murmuring about the midriffe, with a ſucceeding pain in the Reins, have ſoluble and moiſt bellies, unleſſe plenty of wind be voided downward, or much Urine be made, and theſe Symptomes are contingent in Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph 55.
div.p: All women with Child, if they are taken with a Feaver and are very much extenuated, without a manifeſt cauſe, have hard and dangerous Travail, or fall into hazzard of abortment.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 26.
div.p: A raving frees from tremblings in a burning Feaver.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 44.
div.p: The Iliack paſſion ſucceeding a Strangury kills within ſeven dayes, unleſſe plenty of Urine be made, and a Feaver ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 50.
div.p: A Feaver and bilious vomitings muſt of neceſſity ſucceed, when the brain is hurt or periſh'd.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 54.
div.p: Painful breathings with groans are bad in acute Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 52.
div.p: A ſucceeding Feaver doth take away the vehement pain of the Liver.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 65.
div.p: Meat exhibited to one ſick of a Feaver, doth nouriſh the Diſeaſe, but it gives ſtrength to a healthfull and ſound body.

div.head: Diſtinction the ſixth, containing the Aphoriſmes which reſpect the particular Diſeaſes of the whole body, from the head to the foot.

p.hi: AS the parts of the body, ſo are the Diſeaſes thereof divided into external and internal, thoſe which ſpeak of the internal Diſeaſes are interpreted in this Diſtinction, thoſe which touch the external in the following Diſtinction.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Diſeaſes of the head.
Sect. 3. Aph. 13.
div.p: A Summer more than ordinarily dry and cold, and a very wet and warm Autumn, do cauſe head-aches, Coughs, Hoarſeneſſe, Rheums in the Winter, and to ſome Ptiſicks.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 70.
div.p: Troubled water in Feavers, like thoſe made by Kine argue a head-ach preſent, or ſhortly to come.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 28.
div.p: Suffumigations of ſweet odors bring down the monthly evacuations of Women, and were often profitable for other purpoſes, if they did not cauſe a heavineſſe of the head.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 64.
div.p: It is hurtful to give milk to thoſe who are troubled with pains in their head, &c.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 68.
div.p: The breathing of the ſtreight vein in the forehead, takes away the Head-ache of the hinder part of the head.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 10.
div.p:
Matter, water, or blood, flowing out of
the Noſe, the Mouth or Ears, doth take away the Head-ache, and the vehement pains thereof.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 51.
div.p: If ſudden pains of the head happen to healthful bodies, with loſſe of ſpeech, and ſnorting in ſleep accompany, they dye within ſeven days, unleſſe a Feaver lay hold on them.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Lethargie, Dead ſleep, and Congelation.
Sect. 2. Aph. 3.
div.p: EIther ſleeping or waking if they exceed a mean, are ill.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 23.
div.p: In the winter, Pluriſies, Inflamations of the Lungs, and Lethargies, &c.

div.head: Sect. 2. Aph. 42.
div.p: A Confirm'd or ſtrong Apoplexy is incurable, a light one is eaſily cured.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 16.
div.p: Diſeaſes for the moſt part are cauſed by continual rains, as long Feavers, Diarrhaeaes, Rottenneſſe of humours, the Falling Sickneſſe, and Apoplexies.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 23.
div.p: The Diſeaſes of the winter ſeaſon, are Pluriſies, Inflamations of the Lungs, Lethargies, Rheums, Hoarſeneſſe, Coughs, pains of the Breaſt, Sides, and Loins; Head-aches, Megrims, and Apolexies.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 31.
div.p: Diſeaſes incident to old men, are difficulty of breathing, diſtillations cauſing coughs, Stranguries, difficulty of urine, pains of the joynts and reins, Megrims, and Apoplexies.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 51.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſme in the laſt Aphoriſme in the Chapter of the Diſeaſes of the Head.]

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 57.
div.p: Apoplexies do moſt uſually take men from the age of Forty to Threeſcore.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Melancholly, and Madneſſe.
Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: IN the Spring time melancholly, madneſs, the falling ſickneſſe, profuſions of blood, ſquinancies and rheums, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: Many of the Aeſtival Diſeaſes do alſo happen in Autumn. Quartane Feavers, and Erratick, Diſeaſes of the Spleen, Dropſies, Conſumptions, Dropping of Urine, Lienteries, and Dyſenteries, Sciaticks, Squinancies, frequent Aſthmaes, Iliack paſſions, the Falling Evil, Madneſs, and Melancholly.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 9.
div.p: Melancholly perſons are to be purged liberally downward, obſerving the contrary way in contrary affects.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 11.
div.p: The Haemorrhodes (that is a Flux of blood by the veins in the Fundament, by which blood is commonly voided) are conducible and profitable for Melancholly affects, and the Diſeaſes of the Reins.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 21.
div.p: If Melancholly blood be diſpoſed to its proper veins, or if the Haemorrhodes appear, Madneſſe is thereby taken away.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 23.
div.p: Continual fears and ſadneſſe, are ſignes of Melancholly.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 56.
div.p: The inſults and prevailings of Melancholly Diſeaſes, are dangerous, for they foretell a deprivation of ſome part of the body, a Convulſion, Madneſſe, or Blindneſſe.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 5.
div.p: Excoriation of the Bowels, a Dropſie, or a vehement commotion of the mind, coming of Madneſſe, a good ſigne.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 40.
div.p: It is a ſigne of Melancholly if the Tongue ſuddenly be looſe and uſeleſſe, or if any part of the body be deprived of ſenſe and motion.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 30.
div.p:
BUt to ſuch as have paſſed that Age (that is their youth) theſe Diſeaſes are incident
Purſineſſe, Diſeaſes of their Sides, Inflamations of the Lungs, Lethargies and Phrenſies.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 72.
div.p: Very cleer and white Urines are bad: but it eſpecially appears in Phrenetick perſons.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 12.
div.p: A Phrenſie proceeding from an inflamation of the Lungs, is a bad Meſſenger.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 1.
div.p: They do ſeldome perfectly recover which are Phrenetical after the age of fourty years: For they are leſſe endangered to whoſe nature and age the Diſeaſe is familiar.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Delirium or Raving.
Sect. 2. Aph. 2.
div.p: IT is a good ſigne when raving is appeaſed by ſleep.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 53.
div.p: Thoſe alienations of mind which come with laughter, are more ſafe; but thoſe which come by ſeriouſneſſe or ſtudy, are more dangerous.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 7.
div.p: A rigor and raving cauſed by drink, are bad.
Vomiting, the Hicket, or a Convulſion or Raving occaſioned by the Diſeaſe of the thin gut, called Ileum, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 9.
div.p: EIther a Convulſion or Dotage cauſed by a Flux of blood, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 14.
div.p: Stupidity or Dotage occaſioned by a blow received upon the head, is ill.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 18.
div.p: A Convulſion or Dotage cauſed by watching, is naught.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Falling Sickneſſe.
div.p: YOung men are freed from the Falling ſickneſſe chiefly by the mutations of their age, the change of air and dyet.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 7.
div.p: They who are troubled with the Falling Sickneſſe before the age of Fourteen years, are recoverable; but if the Diſeaſe take any at the age of Five and Twenty years, it commonly doth accompany them to their death.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Convulſions, and other affects of the Nerves.
Sect. 2. Aph. 26.
div.p: IT is better that a Feaver come upon a Convulſion, then a Convulſion upon a Feaver.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 25.
div.p: But when they are come to breeding of Teeth pricking pains of the Gums, Feavers and Convulſions, it is bad.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 16.
div.p: It is dangerous giving black Hellebore to ſound bodies, for it cauſeth Convulſions.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 57.
div.p: A Diſenſion of the Nerves or Cramp, or a Convulſion, is cured by a ſucceeding Feaver.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 66.
div.p: Convulſions and violent pains about the bowels, are bad ſignes in acute Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 67.
div.p: Tremblings and Convulſions happening to Feaveriſh perſons, are naught.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 68.
div.p: Interception of Spirits happening in Feavers, is bad, for it ſhews a Convulſion.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 1.
div.p: A Convulſion cauſed by black Hellebore, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 2.
div.p: A Convulſion happening upon a wound received, is deadly.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 3.
div.p: A Convulſion or Hicket coming by a copious Flux of blood, preſageth ill.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 4.
div.p: A Convulſion or Hicket ſucceeding profuſe Purging, are bad.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 5.
div.p: If a Druken man be taken with loſſe of ſpeech on a ſuddain, he dyes convulſive, unleſſe a Feaver ſeize him, or return to his ſpeech at the hour when the diſtemper uſeth to be digeſted.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 6.
div.p: They which are taken with a diſenſion of the Sinews, dye within four dayes, the which if they eſcape, they recover.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 25.
div.p:
Abundance of cold water caſt upon them
which have tumours in their joynts, griefs not ulcerated, gouts and convulſions, for the moſt part, diminiſheth the pain, and takes away the grief; for a moderate ſtupefaction hath a power to take away pain.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 56.
div.p: A Convulſion or Syncope happening to women, in the time of their Purgations, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 65.
div.p: They which have tumours with Ulcers, are ſeldome taken with Convulſions, or droop into Madneſſe. But if they vaniſh backward, the parties are Convulſive, and have diſtenſions of the Nerves. But if they vaniſh forward, either Madneſſe, Pluriſies, Apoſtemes, or Dyſenteries ſucceed, if the tumours were red.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 70.
div.p: They which have Quartan Agues are ſeldome taken with Convulſions. But if they were Convulſive before, they are freed by a ſucceeding Quartan.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 39.
div.p: A Convulſion ariſeth either from emptineſſe or fullneſſe, ſo doth the Hicket.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 56.
div.p: The aſſaults of Melancholly Diſeaſes are dangerous; for they foretell either ſideration of ſome part of the body, Convulſions, Madneſs, or Blindneſs.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 9.
div.p: Doting or a Convulſion by a Flux of blood, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 10.
div.p: Vomiting, Hicket, Convulſion or Delirium, cauſed by the Iliack paſſion, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 13.
div.p: A Convulſion or Cramp cauſed by vehement Inflamations, are bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 18.
div.p: A Convulſion or raving cauſed by watching, are bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 25.
div.p: A Convulſion cauſed by a Purging potion, is mortal.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Stupor or Numneſſe of Senſes.
Sect. 7. Aph. 14.
div.p: A Numneſſe of the Senſes, or dotage cauſed by a hurt on the head, is dangerous.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the affects of the Eyes.
Sect. 3. Aph. 14.
div.p: IF North winds blow much in Autumn, and the ſeaſon be without rain, ſuch a ſeaſon is moſt commodious for bodies of moiſt conſtitution, and to women; but to other conſtitutions it will produce Sore eyes with blood-ſhed in them, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 17.
div.p: North winds condenſe the body, makes them ſtronger, nimbler, of a more lively colour, and in a better plight, dryes the belly, and grieves the Eyes, &c.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 31.
div.p: A potion of wine, a bath, ſomentation, breathing of a vein, or a Purging Medicine, do take away the pains of the Eyes.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 52.
div.p: Regard muſt be had to ſuch things which apappear out of the Eyes in ſleep. For if any thing appear from the White, the Eye-lids being not ſhut, and it doth not happen by a Flux of the belly or a purging potion, it is a bad ſigne, and very mortal.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 3.
div.p: The Hicket and redneſſe of the Eyes cauſed by vomiting, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 46.
div.p: The Diſeaſes of the Eyes muſt be cured by Phlebotomy, draught of Wine being firſt exhibited, and a plenteous bath of warm water.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 2.
div.p: Voluntary tears in Diſeaſes, are good ſignes, but involuntary, are not good.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 15.
div.p: He that hath a Vertigoe with a dark glimmering of his Eyes, and is taken with a Coma or much ſleep, and extreme heat, is in a deſperate Condition.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the affects of the Ears.
Sect. 3. Aph. 5.
div.p: SOuthern winds do produce dulneſſe of hearing, dimneſſe of ſight, and heavineſſe of the head, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 17.
div.p: Southern winds do diſſolve our bodies, moiſten them, and induce difficulty of hearing, heavineſſe of the head, and Vertigoes, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 21.
div.p: In the Summer ſeaſon are continual Feavers, burning Feavers, very many Tertians and Quartans, Vomitings, Diarrhaeaes, ſore Eyes, and pains of the Ears.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 49.
div.p: In continual Feavers, if the lips, eye-lid, eye or noſe be perverted, or turned away, if the ſick neither ſee nor hear, and if he be weak in body, death is at hand.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 60.
div.p: Deafneſſe cauſed by Feavers, is taken away by a ſucceeding Flux of blood out of the Noſtrils, or motions of the belly.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 10.
div.p: Matter, Water, or Blood iſſuing forth by the Noſtrils, by the Mouth, or by the Ears, doth take away head-ach, and the vehement pains thereof.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 14.
div.p: Cold Ears, ſhining, and contracted, are ſignes of death.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Affects of the Noſtrill.
Sect. 2. Aph. 40.
div.p: HOarſeneſſe, and the Flux of humours to the Noſtrils, called in very old men are not concocted.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 13.
div.p: If the Summer be more than ordinary dry, and the wind Northward, but the Autumn exceeding rainy and wet, head-aches ariſe about the winter, coughs, hoarſeneſſe, ſtuffings of the head, and to ſome alſo conſumptions.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: In the Spring ſeaſon, madneſſe, melancholy, the falling Evil, Fluxes of blood, Squinancies, Stuffings of the Head by Rheums, and Coughs are incident.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 27.
div.p: When they have accompliſh'd riper years, and have attained to the Age of fourteen years, many of the former, but rather continual Feavers, and bleeding at the Noſe will follow them.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 74.
div.p:
When there is an Expectation that tumours ſhould ariſe about the joints, plenty of Urine
thick and white frees from the Abſceſs. Tumors of this kind do begin in ſome every fourth day in Feavers with a lazineſſe. But if blood iſſue forth of the noſtrils alſo, then the ſolution will be in a very ſhort ſpace.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 33.
div.p: Bleeding at the noſe happening to Women in the Deficiency of their monthly purgations, is good.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 2.
div.p: They are of a more ſickly Conſtitution which have their Noſtrils, and parts of Generation extraordinary moiſt: but they which are of a contrary conſtitution are more healthful.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 35.
div.p: SNeezing is good for Women that are troubled with a ſuffocation of the Matrix, or who have very hard labour and travail.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 13.
div.p: Sneezing, happening to one that is troubled with the Hicket, takes away the Hicket.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 45.
div.p: Sneezing is either cauſed, the brain being over heated, or the empty part of the head being over moiſtened: For the air there included, is diſperſed abroad; but the noiſe made by ſneezing is occaſioned, becauſe the included hath its paſſage by ſtreight and narrow inſtruments.

div.head: Sect. 2. Aph. 40.
div.p: HOarſeneſſe and Rheums in very old men, are not concocted.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Affects of the Mouth and Tongue.
Sect. 3. Aph. 21.
div.p: IN the Summer ſeaſon, Diaries, Burning Feavers, and very many Tertian and Quartans, Vomitings, Diarrhaeaes, Bleer eyes, pains of the Ears; Exulcerations of the mouth, putrid Ulcers about the Privities, and Pimples cauſed by Cholerick Sweats.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 24.
div.p: Spreading Ulcers of the mouth called Apthae, are a Diſeaſe common to young Infants and Children.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 32.
div.p: Stammerers are moſt of all taken with a long Flux of the Belly.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 40.
div.p: It is a ſigne of black Choler when the tongue is looſe and uſeleſſe on a ſuddain, or when any part of the body becommeth benummed or dead.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 9.
div.p: If the Tongue be neither black, nor bloody, if either of theſe Signes be abſent, it is no very bad Signe. For hereby is ſignified a leſſer Diſeaſe.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Affects of the Teeth.
Sect. 3. Aph. 25.
div.p: BUt when they are come to breeding of their Teeth, Pricking, Itchings of the Gums, Feavers, Convulſions, Fluxes of the belly, and then chiefly when they begin to breed their Dog Teeth, and to thoſe who are of a groſſe conſtitution, and who are coſtive.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 53.
div.p: Thoſe Feavers are moſt vehement, whereby a clammy gluttinous humour doth grow to the Teeth.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 18.
div.p: Cold things are offenſive to the bones, teeth, nerves, brain, and marrow of the back-bone, but hot things are profitable.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Affects of the Lips and Gums.
Sect. 4. Aph. 49.
div.p: IN continual Feavers, if the Lip, Eye-lid, Eye or Noſe be perverted and turned, if the ſick neither ſee nor hear, and his Body be weak, then death is nigh at hand.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 13.
div.p: Wan lips or pale, or reſolved, turned in and out, and cold, are mortal.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Affects of the Throat, Squinancy, and Aſthma.
Sect 2. Aph. 43.
div.p: AMongſt thoſe who are ſtrangled, and diſſolved, and are not quite dead, they ſeldome or very rarely return to life, which have froth gathered together about their mouth.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 16.
div.p: Diſeaſes are uſually cauſed by continual ſhowers, as long Feavers, Fluxes of the belly, putrid Feavers, the falling ſickneſſe, Apoplexies and Squinancies, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: In the ſpring ſeaſon, Melancholly, Madneſſe, the Falling-Evil, profuſions of blood, and Squinancies, &c.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 34.
div.p: A Strangulation happening to him that is Sick of a Feaver, no tumour appearing in the Jaws, is deadly.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 35.
div.p: In Feavers a ſudden perverting of the neck happening, ſo that the Sick can hardly ſwallow, no tumour appearing, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 10.
div.p: Humours falling down to the Throat, if they turn not to the Squinancy they ſettle upon the Lungs, and the Sick dyes within ſeven dayes; but if he eſcape that time, the matter turns to Impoſtumation.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 37.
div.p: It is a good Sign if in a Squinancy, a Tumor do appear in the neck, for then the morbifick matter is ſent forth.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 46.
div.p: They which are made Crook-back'd by an Aſthma, dye before they come to the Age of Fourteen years, or ſoon after.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 49.
div.p: An impoſtumation or redneſſe happening in the breaſt of him that hath a Squinancy, is a good ſigne. Becauſe the matter is excluded to the external parts.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the affects of the Breaſt and Lungs, and firſt of the Difficulty of Breathing.
Sect. 3. Aph. 43.
div.p:
IN the Winter ſeaſon, pluriſies, inflamations of the lungs, lethargies, rheums, hoarſeneſſe,
coughs, pains of the breaſts, ſides, and loins, head-aches, megrims, and apoplexies, are common.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 31.
div.p: Difficulty of breathing, catarrhes cauſing coughs, the ſtrangury and difficulty of Urine, are Diſeaſes familiar to old Age.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 50.
div.p: If difficulty of breathing, and dotings happen in continual Feavers, it is mortal.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of Hoarſeneſſe and the Cough.
Sect. 2. Aph. 40.
div.p: HOarſeneſſe and rheums in very Old men, are not concocted.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph 5.
div.p: But if the ſeaſon be dry and cold, it cauſeth coughs, exaſperates the jawes, hardeneth the belly and ſuppreſſeth Urine.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 13.
div.p: But if the Summer be more then uſually dry and cold with North-winds, and the Autumn rainy with South-winds, expect head-aches, in the winter, coughs, hoarſeneſſe, rheums, and to ſome conſumptions.

div.head: Sect 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: But in the Spring, madneſſe, melancholly, the falling ſickneſſe, profuſions of blood, ſquinancies rheums, hoarſeneſſe and coughs will follow.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 24.
div.p: Theſe Diſeaſes happen to infants and children newly born, ſpreading Ulcers of the mouth, called Aphthae, vomitings and coughs.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 31.
div.p: Difficulty of breathing, and diſtillations inferring coughs do happen to old men.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 54.
div.p: If dry coughs lightly provoking happen in burning Feavers, and perſevere long, the ſick is not then much troubled with thirſt.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 24.
div.p: Cold things, as ice and ſnow, are offenſive and enemies to the breaſt, they cauſe coughs, eruptions of blood, and catarrhes.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 35.
div.p: A Cough happening in a Dropſie is a bad ſign.

div.head: Sect 6. Aph. 46.
div.p: If crookedneſs were occaſioned by an Aſthma, the party thus affected dyes before he attain the age of Fourteen years, or preſently after.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 47.
div.p: If a cough do hold him that hath a Dropſie, he is in a deſperate condition.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of hurt of Sp • ech.
Sect. 5. Aph. 5.
div.p: IF loſs of Speech happen on a ſuddain to a Drunken man, he dyes convulſive, unleſſe a Feaver lay hold on him, and his Speech return to him at the hour when nature uſeth to digeſt the Surfet.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 52.
div.p: They which are taken with ſudden pains of the head, and were not ſick before, and if their Speech fail or leave them, and a ſnorting commeth withal, dye within ſeven dayes, unleſſe a Feaver lay hold on them.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 58.
div.p: Loſſe of Speech muſt neceſſary enſue preſently if the brain have bin hurt by any occaſion.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of Inflamation of the Lungs.
Sect. 3. Aph. 23.
div.p: BUt in the winter pluriſies, inflamations of the lungs, and lethargies.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 30.
div.p: But to thoſe who are in their youth, thickneſſe of breathing, Diſeaſes of the Sides, and inflamations of the Lungs are incident.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 16.
div.p: A Diarrhaea or Flux of the belly, ſucceeding the pluriſie or inflamation of the lungs, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 11.
div.p: Inflamation of the lungs ſucceeding a Pluriſie, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 12.
div.p: A phrenſie occaſioned by an inflamation of the lungs, ſignifies ill.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of Empyema, or Suppuration of the Lungs.
Sect. 5. Aph. 8.
div.p: IF pluretick perſons are not clenſed within Fourteen dayes, the matter turns to impoſtumation.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 10.
div.p: Humours falling to the Throat, if they turn not to a ſquinancy, ſettle upon the Lungs, and the ſick dye within ſeven dayes, but if they eſcape that time, the matter turns to ſuppuration.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 15.
div.p: If pluretick perſons being ſuppurated are purged and clenſed within forty days, they are freed, otherwiſe do grow conſumptive.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 65.
div.p: They, in whoſe bodies ulcerated tumours do ariſe, are neither taken with convulſions, nor driven into madneſſe; but theſe tumours ſuddenly vaniſhing, they to whom it happens in the back parts have convulſions and diſtenſions of the Sinews; but if it happen in the fore part, ragings and acute Diſeaſes of the ſides, impoſtumations, and dyſenteries do follow.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 27.
div.p: They certainly dye, who are either burnt or cut for an impoſtumation of the breaſt, or for a Dropſie, if matter or water ſlow forth upon heaps.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 41.
div.p: When an impoſtumation is in the body, and it gives no ſignification of it ſelf, the want of that diſcovery is either cauſed by the thickneſſe of the matter, or place wherein it is contained.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 15.
div.p: Spitting of ſuppurated matter from ſpitting of blood is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 38.
div.p: Diſtillations upon the upper ventricle are turned into ſuppuration within the twentieth day.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 44.
div.p: When ſuppurated perſons are cauterized or lanced, if pure and white matter iſſue forth they eſcape, but if it be ſomewhat bloody, filthy and ill favoured they periſh.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of the Ptyſick or Conſumption.
Sect. 4. Aph. 48.
div.p: A Dry and cold Summer with North winds, and a wet Autumn with South winds, cauſe head-aches in the winter, coughs, hoarſneſſe and rheums, and to ſome conſumptions.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: Many Diſeaſes which are uſually in the Summer, appear in the Autumn, as quartane and erratick Feavers, diſeaſes of the ſpleen, dropfies, conſumptions, lienteries, and dyſenteries, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 29.
div.p: Young▪men are afflicted with ſpittings of blood, conſumptions, acute feavers, the falling evil, and many other Diſeaſes, but eſpecially thoſe mentioned.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 8.
div.p: In purging conſumptive perſons, we muſt be very wary, and fearfull in exhibiting vomitive medicines.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 9.
div.p: Conſumptions happen eſpecially from the eighteenth year of our age, until the five and thirtieth year.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 11.
div.p: It is a mortal ſign when the ſpittle of ſuch as are in a conſumption being caſt upon the coals ſends forth a grievous ſmell, if the hair of the head fall off likewiſe.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 12.
div.p: It is an argument of death when the hair of the head of conſumptive perſons falls off, if a looſeneſſe of the belly ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph 13.
div.p: Frothy blood caſt forth by ſpittle, is voided from the Lungs.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 14.
div.p: A Flux of the belly is mortal to conſumptive perſons.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 12.
div.p: In the curing of the Hemorrhoids or piles, unleſſe one vein be left open, there is danger that a dropſie or conſumption will ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 16.
div.p: A conſumption, and flux are cauſed by ſpitting out ſuppurated matter. But when the ſpitting ceaſeth, the ſick dye.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 7.
div.p: [You have this Aphoriſme before in the ſame Chapter. Aph. 5. whether I refer you.]

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 8.
div.p: All things which incline or tend to conſumptions, are vehement, but ſome are mortal; but it would be advantageous if the Diſeaſe ſhould ſeiſe the body at ſuch a time when the ſeaſon did afford ſome help for the Diſeaſe, as the Summer for a burning Feaver, the Winter for the Dropſie; for that which is according to nature doth obtain the victory, but in the Diſeaſes of the Spleen, it is rather cauſe of fear.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 23.
div.p: BUt in the Winter ſeaſon, pluriſies, inflamations of the lungs, and apoplexies.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 8.
div.p: If Pluretick perſons are not clenſed within fourteen dayes, the matter turns to impoſtumation.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 15.
div.p: Pluretick perſons being ſuppurated, if they are clenſed within forty dayes after the impoſtume is broke, are freed, otherwiſe they grow into a conſumption.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 5.
div.p: We muſt learn whether the pains in the ſides, in the breaſt, and in other parts do differ much.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 6.
div.p: A Flux of the belly ſucceeding a pluriſie, or the inflamation of the lungs, is a bad ſigne.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 33.
div.p: They which have ſour belchings, are not much troubled with pluriſies.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 11.
div.p: An inflamation of the lungs coming upon a pluriſie, is bad.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of ſpitting of Blood.
Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: YOung men are troubled with ſpittings of blood, conſumptions, acute feavers, the falling ſickneſſe, and many other Diſeaſes, but eſpecially theſe.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 25.
div.p: Any blood whatſoever voided upward, is bad, but if black blood be voided downward, it is good.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 13.
div.p: Frothy blood caſt forth by ſpittle, is brought from the lungs.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 10.
div.p: Matter, water, or blood, voided by the noſtrils, the mouth, or the ears, take away the headache, and the vehement pains thereof.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 37.
div.p: Vomiting of blood happening without a feaver is good, but bad with a feaver, and the diſtemper muſt be cured with ſuch Medicines which have a cooling and reſtringent quality in them.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. Of the affects of the Heart.
Sect. 2. Aph. 36.
div.p: MEn of unblameable and perfect health, do quickly faint when they are purged, and ſuch alſo who uſe ill dyet.

div.head: Sect. 2. Aph. 41.
div.p: Such as are often and violently taken with a Sincope or Swounding without ſome manifeſt cauſe, dye ſuddenly.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 17.
div.p: Abhorring of meat, gnawing of the mouth of the ſtomach, a vertigoe withdrowſineſs, and a bitterneſs in the mouth, without a feaver, do inſtruct us that purging by vomit is neceſſary.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 56.
div.p: A Convulſion, or Sincope happening to women in the time of their purgations, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 8.
div.p: Faintings, vomitings, and ſwoundings, are cauſed by the rupture of a tumour inwardly.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of the affects of the Breaſts.
Sect. 5. Aph. 37.
div.p: IF the Breaſts of a woman with Child, grow ſlender on a ſuddain▪ ſhe is in danger of aborting, or miſcarrying.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 38.
div.p: If one of the Breaſts of a woman with Child with Twins, grow ſlender, ſhe will abort with one of her Children; and if the right Breaſt grow ſlender, ſhe will miſcarry a Male, if the left, a Female.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 39.
div.p: If a woman which neither is with Child, nor never had Child, have milk in her Breaſts, her monthly purgations have failed.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 40.
div.p:
When blood is gathered together into a tumour of ſwelling about the Breaſts, raging or
madneſſe, is thereby ſignified to thoſe women.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 50.
div.p: If you would ſtop the flowing of womens courſes, apply very large Cupping-glaſſes to their breaſts.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 52.
div.p: Plenty of milk runing forth of the Breaſts of women with Child, argue a weak Child; but if the breaſts are ſolid, they argue a more ſtrong Child,

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 53.
div.p: They which are like to miſcarry, will have ſlender breaſts, but if their breaſts grow hard, they will have a pain in the breaſts, or in the hips, in their eyes, or in their knees, and will not miſcarry.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. Of the affects of the Stomach.
Sect. 1. Aph. 15.
div.p: IN the winter and ſpring our ſtomachs are moſt hot, and our ſleeps moſt long, therefore in thoſe ſeaſons our meals ought to be more plentiful, becauſe when there is moſt natural heat our bodies need more plentiful nutriment, which Ages, and Wreſtlers ſignifie unto us.

div.head: Sect. 2. Aph. 21.
div.p: A draught of Wine takes away hunger.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 65.
div.p: A vehement heat of the Stomach, and a gnawing of the mouth of the ſtomach in Feavers, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 7.
div.p: Pains of the Stomach, which are in the upper part thereof, are more light, and not ſo vehement as thoſe which are in the lower part thereof.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 18.
div.p: It is mortal, if the bladder, brain, heart, midriffe, any thin inteſtine or bowel, the ſtomach or liver be peirced or divided.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 54.
div.p: When Phlegm is included between the midriffe and the ſtomach, if it cauſe pain, and have no paſſage either way, if it be turned into the bladder by the veins, the Diſeaſes are diſſolved.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 6.
div.p: Abhorring of meat and ſincere dejections in a continual Feaver, fortell ill.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 18.
div.p:
When the vital ſpirits above the navil aſcend above the Diaphragma, all the humour is burnt up then death is come. But when the lungs and heart, having loſt their radical moiſture, the heat being gathered together into mortiferous places, breath forth the ſpirits of heat altogether. Moreover partly by the fleſh, partly by the pores of the head, by which we ſay we live, the Soul leave
the Cottage of the body, yeilds up this cold and mortal Effigies, together with the choler, blood, flegm and fleſh.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 19.
div.p: THey which having taken a purging potion, and are not thirſty while they purge, will not leave purging, until they do thirſt.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 48.
div.p: To have the outward parts cold, and the inward burn with a vehement thirſt, is mortal in continual feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 54.
div.p: If one ſick of a burning feaver, have a long dry cough lightly provoking, he is not much vexed with thirſt.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 27.
div.p: It is a good ſigne, if ſuch as have a deſire to drink in the night, do fall aſleep while they are thirſty.

div.head: Sect. 1. Aph. 2.
div.p: IN vomitings and going to ſtool, which come of their own accord, if ſuch things are voided which ought to be purged, it is conducible, and it is born with eaſe; but if not, it ſucceeds otherwiſe, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 24.
div.p: Diſeaſes common to Infants and young Children are ſpreading Ulcers of the mouth, vomitings, coughs, watchings, tremblings, inflamations about the navil, and moiſtneſſe of the Ears.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 4.
div.p: It is moſt convenient to purge by Vomit in the Summer, in the winter, by ſtool.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 6.
div.p: Thinne bodies and ſuch as vomit with eaſe, are to be purged by vomitive Medicines, being very watry and fearful of the winter ſeaſon.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph 7.
div.p:
But ſuch as vomit with difficulty, and are moderately groſſe, ought to be purged down
• ard, but we muſt be very cautious in the •… mmer.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 8.
div.p: We muſt be very wary and fearful in purging conſumptive perſons by vomit.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 12.
div.p: It is very inconvenient to purge ſuch as have a Lientery by vomit in the winter time.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 13.
div.p: Bodies which do not vomit eaſily after they have taken black Hellebore muſt be moiſtened with plenty of meat and reſt before they take their Phyſick,

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 17.
div.p: Abhorring of meat, gnawings of the mouth of the ſtomach, a dizzineſſe in the head, with a dimneſſe of the eyes without a Feaver, if the mouth be bitter, ſhew unto us that a vomit is neceſſary.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 18.
div.p: Pains above the midriffe, if they ought to be purged, tell us that they ought to be purged by a Medicine that will purge upward. But if they are beneath the midriffe, then they muſt be purged downward.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 22.
div.p: It is a deadly ſign if melancholſy blood be voided either upward or downward at the beginning of any Diſeaſe whatſoever.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 25.
div.p:
Any blood caſt forth upward is bad, bu •
if black blood be voided downwards, it is good.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 32.
div.p: Vomiting of blood is ſtayed and taken away by the eruption of the monthly purgations.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 3.
div.p: The Hicket and redneſſe of the eyes occaſioned by vomiting, is a bad ſigne.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 8.
div.p: Faintings, vomiting, and ſwoundings, are cauſed by the rupture of a tumour inwardly.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 10.
div.p: Vomiting, Hicket, or Delirium, cauſed by the Iliacke paſſion, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 37.
div.p: Vomiting of blood, if it happen without a feaver, is wholſome, but bad with a feaver, and it muſt be cured with cooling and reſtringent Medicines.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 70.
div.p: When we intend to purge the body, it ought to be made ſoluble; if you would have them fluxible upwards, you muſt ſtay the belly, but if downward, it is to be moiſtned.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 3.
div.p: A Convulſion or Hicket coming by a large effuſion of blood, doth foretell ill.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 4.
div.p: The Hicket ſucceeding over much purging, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: The Strangury ſucceeds an inflamation of the wombe, and of the ſtreight gut, and ſuppurated Reins. But the Hicket ſucceeds, if the liver be grieved with an inflamation.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 13.
div.p: If ſneezings happen to him that hath the Hicket, they take away the Hicket.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 39.
div.p: A convulſion ariſeth of too much fulneſſe or emptineſſe, ſo alſo doth the Hicket.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 3.
div.p: The Hicket or redneſſe of the eyes, cauſed by vomiting, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 10.
div.p: Vomiting, hicket, convulſion or dotage cauſed by the Iliack paſſion, portends ill.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 17.
div.p: The Hicket coming by the inflamation of the liver, is very bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 41.
div.p: It is no good ſigne if the hicket happen to elderly perſons, being over much purged.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Of the affects of the Midriffe.
Sect. 4. Aph. 64.
div.p: IF the yellow Jaundice come to a Feaveriſh perſon, the ſeventh, ninth, eleventh, or fourteenth day, it is good, unleſſe the right Hypochondrium be hard, otherwiſe it is leſſe good.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 73.
div.p: They whoſe midriffe is elevated and rumbles, with a ſucceeding pain of the Loins, have moiſt bellies, unleſſe wind break forth backward, or plenty of urine be voided, theſe accidents are contingent in Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 64.
div.p: Milk is inconvenient for thoſe who have the head-ache, neither is it to be allowed in Feavers or to ſuch whoſe Diaphragma being elevated have rumbling noiſes, &c.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 40.
div.p: When there are grieſs about the Midriffe without an inflamation, a ſucceeding feaver doth take away the grief.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Of the affects of the Liver.
Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: A Strangury ſucceeds an inflamation of the ſtreight inteſtine, and of the wombe and ſuppurated Reins, but the hicket ſucceeds when the Liver is inflamed.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 18.
div.p: If either the bladder, brains, heart, midriffe or any thin bowel, ſtomach, or liver be peirced or cut, death enſues.

div.head: Sect. 9. Aph. 42.
div.p: A Stirrus of the liver ſucceeding to them which have the yellow Jaundies, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 17.
div.p: The Hicket coming by the inflamation of the liver, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 45.
div.p: If any man be cut or burnt for the ſuppuration of the liver, if pure matter and white follow, they ſurvive, but if matter like the Lees of Oyle proceed, they periſh.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 55.
div.p: If the liver full of water empty it ſelf upon the kell, the belly is fill'd with water, and the ſick dyes.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: IN the Autumn many Eſtival Diſeaſes happen, and Quartan and Erratick Feavers, Diſeaſes of the Spleen, Dropſies, Conſumptions, &c.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 11.
div.p: When the bowels are wound and wreſted about, great pains about the navil, and grief of the Loins are concomitant, the which if it be not cured by a purging Medicine, nor any other means, is confirmed into a dry Dropſie.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 8.
div.p: Ulcers ariſing in the bodies of Hydropical perſons, are not eaſily cured.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 11.
div.p: In the Dropſie if the water flow forth of the veins into the belly, the Diſeaſe is diſſolved.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 27.
div.p:
Empiecal, or Hydropical perſons being burnt or cut, if either water or ſuppurated matter
abundantly flow forth, the ſick certainly dye.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 35.
div.p: A cough happening to him that is ſick of the Dropſie, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 5.
div.p: A dyſentery, Dropſie, or a vehement commotion of the mind, ſucceeding raging or madneſſe, is good.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 55.
div.p: If an Hydropical liver iſſue violently forth upon the kell, the belly is fill'd with water, and the ſick dyes.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 62.
div.p: IT is no good ſigne if the Yellow Jaundies do ſucceed a Feaver before the ſeventh day.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 64.
div.p: If the Jaundies coming upon a Feaver do appear the ſeventh, ninth, eleventh, or fourteenth day, the Criſis is good, unleſſe the right Hypochondrium be hard, otherwiſe it is not good.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 72.
div.p: Icterical perſons are not much ſubject to wind.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 42.
div.p: It is an ill ſign, if he that hath the Jaundies have a Scirrhus of the Liver.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. Of the affects of the Spleen.
Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: MAny Diſeaſes frequent in the Summer happen alſo in the Autumn, and Quartan and Erratick feavers, and Diſeaſes of the Spleen, &c.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 43.
div.p: When ſuppurated matter is in the body, and doth not exhibit any ſignification of it ſelf, the cauſe either is from the groſſeneſſe of the matter, or of the place where it reſideth.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 48.
div.p: A Dyſentery coming in ſpleenetick perſons, is good.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX. Of the Flux of the Belly or Diarrhaea.
Sect. 2. Aph. 14.
div.p: CHanges of the excrements in the flux of the belly are good, unleſſe they change to bad.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 16.
div.p: Diſeaſes are uſually cauſed by continual ſhowers, or rain; as long Feavers, Diarrhaeaes, putrid feavers, the falling ſickneſs and apoplexies.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 25.
div.p: When Children are breeding their teeth, itching and prickings of the gums, feavers, convulſions, fluxes of the belly do afflict them, and then more eſpecially when they have begun to put forth their dog teeth, and to thoſe moſt cheifly, who are of a more groſſe conſtitution, and have their bellies hard.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 30.
div.p: But to thoſe who are now paſt their youth, frequent Aſthmaes, pluriſies, inflamations of the lungs, lethargies, phrenſies, burning Feavers, continual Diarrhaeaes, choler, dyſenteries, lienteries, and flux of blood by the Haemorrhoidical veins in the Fundament.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 21.
div.p: Black excrements like dreggiſh or black blood proceeding without provocation either with a Feaver, or without a feaver, are very bad, and ſo much the worſe by how much the more their colour are many and bad. But if they are cauſed by a medicine, they are ſo much the better, by how much their colours are many, and not bad.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 22.
div.p:
An iſſue of black blood, either upward or
downward at the beginning of any Diſeaſe whatſoever, is deadly.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 23.
div.p: If voiding of black choler, like dreggiſh or black blood, ſhall follow to ſuch whoſe bodies are attenuated, either by acute feavers, or continual Feavers, by wounds or any other means, the patient dyes the day following.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 24.
div.p: A dyſentery cauſed by melancholly blood, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 26.
div.p: If little peices of fleſh are voided by ſtool, by him that hath an exulceration of the bowels, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 28.
div.p: Bilious dejections ceaſe if deafneſſe enſue, and deafneſſe is taken away by bilious dejections ſucceeding.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 12.
div.p: When the hairs of conſumptive perſons fall off, a flux of the belly ſucceeds, and they dye.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 14.
div.p: A Diarrhaea coming upon a conſumptive perſon, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 34.
div.p: If a woman with Child be taken with an extreme looſeneſſe, ſhe is in danger of aborting.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 65.
div.p: They to whom tumours with ulcers do appear are neither taken by convulſion, nor driven into rage or madneſſe. But they preſently vaniſhing, to ſuch to whom this happeus backwards, convulſions, and diſtenſions of the nerves are cauſed; but if it happen forwards, ragings, acute diſeaſes of the ſides, ſuppuration of humours, or a dyſentery doth happen, if the tumors were red.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 3.
div.p: Abhorring of meat in long dyſenteries is not good, but worſe if it come with a feaver.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 15.
div.p: A Diarrhaea which▪ hath continued long, is taken away by a voluntary vomiting; ſucceeding.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 16.
div.p: A flux of the belly coming upon a pluriſie or or an inflamation of the lungs, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 17.
div.p: It is beneficial for thoſe which are troubled with ſore eyes, to be taken with a looſeneſſe of the belly.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 52.
div.p: We muſt obſerve what things appear from the eyes by ſleep, for if from the white, the eye-lids being open any thing appear, and not cauſed by a flux of the belly, or a purging▪ Medicine, it is a bad ſigne, and very mortal.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 43.
div.p: Splenetick perſons which are afflicted with a dyſentery, after a long ſucceeding dyſentery, a dropſie or lientery happens, and they dye.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 48.
div.p: A dyſentery coming upon the Spleen, is good.

div.head: Sect 7. Aph. 5.
div.p: A dyſentery, dropſie, or an Exſtaſis coming upon raging or madneſſe, is good.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 23.
div.p: A dyſentery ſucceeds ſincere dejections.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 29.
div.p: A vehement flux of the belly cures that kind of dropſie which comes of white pituite, and is called Lecophlegmatia.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 30.
div.p: Frothy excrements voided by ſtool come from the brain.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 75.
div.p: A dyſentery ſucceeds a Diarrhaea.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 76.
div.p: A lientery ſucceeds a dyſentery.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 5.
div.p: A flux of the belly ſucceeding a long Diſeaſe, is bad.

div.head: CHAP. XL. Of a Dyſentery or Excoriation of the Bowels.
Sect. 4. Aph. 24.
div.p: THat dyſentery is mortal which was cauſed by black choler.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 26.
div.p: In a dyſentery, if ſmall peices of fleſh are ejected by ſtool, the Diſeaſe is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 43.
div.p: Splenetick perſons afflicted with a dyſentery, after a long excoriation of the bowels, a dropſie or lientery ſucceed, and they dye.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. Of a Lientery or levity of the Bowels.
Sect. 4. Aph. 12.
div.p: IT is dangerous purging lienterical perſons by vomiting Medicines in the winter ſeaſon.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 1.
div.p: If ſowre belchings, which were not before, ſucceed a long lientery or levity of the bowels, it is a good ſigne.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 15.
div.p: A voluntary vomiting happening to him which hath had a long flux, doth take away the flux.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. Of the Iliack Paſſion.
Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: MAny Aeſtival Diſeaſes happen in the Autumn, and Quartan and Erratick Feavers, Diſeaſes of the Spleen, Dropſies, Conſumptions, dropping of the Urine, Lienteries, Dyſenteries, pains of the Hips, Squinances, frequent Aſthmaes, Iliack paſſions, the Falling Evil, Madneſſe, and Melancholly Diſeaſes.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 44.
div.p: If the Iliack paſſion ſucceed a Strangury, the Sick dyes within ſeven dayes, unleſſe plenty of urine be voided, and a feaver ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 10.
div.p: Vomiting, Hicket, a Convulſion or Dotage occaſioned by the Diſeaſe of the thin bowel called Ileum, is bad.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. Of the pain of the Belly.
Sect. 4. Aph. 11.
div.p: VVHen the Bowels are wrung or wreſted, pains are felt about the navil, and grief of the loins, is preſent; if the diſtemper be cured neither by a purging Medicine, nor any other means, it is confirmed into a dry dropſie.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 65.
div.p: A vehement heat about the belly, and a gnawing of the mouth of the Stomach, is a bad ſigne in Feavers.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 5.
div.p: We muſt obſerve and learn whether the pains of the breaſt, ſides, and of other places are much different, or not.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 7.
div.p: Pains which are cauſed about the belly, if they are high and ſublime, are more light and eaſie, but if they are not ſublime, they are more vehement.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 40.
div.p: A ſucceeding Feaver diſſolves ſuch pains which ariſe about the Diaphragme, without an inflamation.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 22.
div.p: Suppuration or impoſtumation is cauſed by a continual grief of thoſe parts which appertain to the belly.
A coldneſs or chilneſs of the extreme parts, cauſed by a vehement grief of the parts which belong to the belly, is bad.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 29.
div.p: He that piſſeth blood, and ſtuffe like curdled milk, and hath the Strangury; if the grief extend it ſelf to the Rorinaeum; lower belly, and parts about the privities, hath a defection in thoſe parts which appertain to the bladder.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV. Of Teneſmus or often deſire to go to stoole.
Sect. 7. Aph. 27.
div.p: IF a Tenoſmus or an often and vain deſire of going to ſtool, without voiding any thing, happen unto women with Child, it will cauſe abortion or miſcarriage.

div.head: CHAP. XLV. Of the affect of the Fundament and Hamorrhoides.
Sect. 3. Aph. 30.
div.p: THey which are beyond their youth, frequent Aſthmaes, pluriſies, inflamations of the lungs, lethargies, phrenſies, burning and continual feavers, Diarrhaeaes, cholers, excoriations of the bowels, lienteries, and profuſion of blood by the veins in the fundament, called the Haemorrhoides.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 25.
div.p: Evacuations of blood upward, be the blood of what condition ſoever, is bad; but if black blood, be caſt down beneath, it is good.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 11.
div.p: The Haemorrhoides, or a flux of blood by the mouth of the veins in the fundament, whereby nature doth uſually eaſe it ſelf, are convenient and beneficial in melancholly affects and Diſeaſes of the Reins.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 12.
div.p: In the cure of the Haemorrhoides, or continual flux of blood, by the veins in the Fundament, unleſſe one vein be preſerved and kept, there is danger that a dropſie or conſumption may ſucceed.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 21.
div.p: If the veins do ſwell with melancholly blood, or if the Haemorrhoidical veins flow and empty the body of blood, madneſſe is thereby diſſolved.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI. Of the affects of the Reins.
Sect. 3. Aph. 3.
div.p: DIſeaſes accompaning old age, are difficulty of breathing, Catarrhes cauſing coughs, ſtranguries, difficulty of piſſing, pains of the joynts and the reins, &c.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 75.
div.p: An exulceration of the reins or bladder, is ſignified by blood or ſuppurated matter, ſent forth with the Urine.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 76.
div.p: Small peices of fleſh or ſomething like hairs carried out with the Urine, are ſent from the reins.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 78.
div.p: Blood iſſuing forth freely with the Urine, doth ſignifie the rupture of a vein in the reins.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: A Strangury ſucceeds an inflamation of the ſtreight inteſtine, an inflamation of the wombe, and a ſuppuration of the reins.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 6.
div.p: The vices of the reins and bladder in old men are hardly cured.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 11.
div.p: The Hemorrhoides or blood ſent forth by the veins in the fundament, is beneficial in melancholy affects and Diſeaſes of the reins.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 34.
div.p: Bubbles ſtanding on the top of the Urine, do ſignifie a Diſeaſe of the reins, and the length thereof.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 35.
div.p: When the upper part or ſuperficies of the Urine is fat and greaſie, thick and gathered together, then is ſignified a Diſeaſe of the reins, and that a ſharp one too.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 36.
div.p: But when the aforeſaid ſignes do happen in thoſe whoſe reins are Diſeaſed, and pains are felt about the Muſcles of the back bone, if they are carried to the external parts, expect that the abſceſs will be external; but if they tend more to the inward parts, it is to be feared that the abſceſs will be inward.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII. Of the Affects of the Privities.
Sect. 3. Aph. 21.
div.p: IN the Summer time ſome of theſe Diſeaſes, and continual and burning feavers, very many tertians and quartans, vomitings; fluxes of the belly, ſore eyes, pains of the ears, exulcerations of the mouth, corruptions of the privities, and ſmall puſtles cauſed by cholerick Sweats.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 42.
div.p: A ſmall Ulcer growing in the Yard, if there happen a ſuppuration, and break, a ſolution ſucceeds.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 22.
div.p: Heat cauſing ſuppuration doth not exhibit unto us the certaineſt ſignes of ſecurity in every ulcer, it ſoftens the skin, extenuates it, takes away pain, aſwage rigors, convulſions, and cramps, diſſolves heavineſſe of the head, is very much available for broken bones, and for ſuch eſpecially which are bare of fleſh, and for thoſe cheifly who have ulcers in their head, for ſuch alſo who are ſtupified with cold, or are ulcerated for creeping, and eating ſores in the fundament, yard, wombe, and bladder; to all theſe things heat is acceptable, and doth cauſe a criſis, but cold is an enemy, and deſtructive.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 62.
div.p: Women which have cold and condens'd wombes, do not conceive, nor they whoſe wombes are overmolſt, for in ſuch the ſeed is extinguiſhed, neither ſuch who have extraordinary dry wombes and very hot, for in thoſe the ſeed is corrupted for want of nutriment. But ſuch who have naturally a moderate temperature, between thoſe two extremes, do prove fruitful.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 63.
div.p: There is the ſame reaſon alſo in men, for either by reaſon of the rarity of the body, the ſpirit is diffuſed abroad, ſo that it cannot ſend forth the ſeed, or by reaſon of its conſtipation or thickneſs the humour cannot be ſent forth, or by reaſon of its coldneſs, the ſeed is not heated, ſo that it may be gathered to its proper place, or the ſame may happen by heat.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 19.
div.p: If a bone, a griſſel, a nerve, or any ſmall particle of the jaw bone, or the foreskin of the yard, be divided or cut a ſunder, it is neither nouriſhed, neither doth it grow together again.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII. Of the affects of the Bladder.
Sect. 3. Aph. 5.
div.p: IF the ſeaſon of the year be cold with Northwinds, it cauſeth coughs, exaſperates the jawes, hardeneth the belly, ſuppreſſeth urine, cauſeth horrors, and pains of the ſides and breaſt; when it ſo prevaileth ſuch accidents are to beexpected in Diſeaſes.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 16.
div.p: Great Droughts cauſe conſumptions, ſore eyes, pains of the joynts and ſtranguries, with Diſeaſes of the bowels.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: In the Autumn many Summer Diſeaſes do happen, and quartan and erratick feavers, Diſeaſes of the ſpleen, dropſies, conſumptions, the ſtrangury, lienteries and dyfenteries.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 31.
div.p: Theſe Diſeaſes are contingent to old men, Aſthmaes, catarrhes, the ſtrangury, ſtopping of urine, and pains of the joynts and reins.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 69.
div.p: Urines in Feavers, if they change from thick, and ſuch as have curdled ſtuffe in them, and few, too many and thin do eaſe the patient, eſpecially if ſuch are made wherein there appears a ſediment at the beginning, or not long after.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 70.
div.p: Troubleſome Urines, like thoſe of kine in Feavers, argue either the head-ache to be preſent, or to enſue.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 71.
div.p: When a Criſis doth happen the ſeventh day, the urine hath a red cloud the fourth day, and other things anſwerable thereunto.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 74.
div.p: When an abſceſs is expected to the joynts plenty of urine thick and white, frees from the abſceſs, &c.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 72.
div.p: Cleer and white urines are all bad, but that appears chiefly in Phrenetick perſons.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 73.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſm in the Chapter of the affects of the Hypocondries.]

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 75.
div.p: If blood or corrupt matter be ſent forth with the urine, an exulceration of the reins is thereby ſignified.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 76.
div.p: When ſmall peices of fleſh, or things like hairs are carried forth with the urine, they are brought from the reins.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 77.
div.p: When things like bran are voided with the urine, the bladder hath a ſcab.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 79.
div.p: Blood iſſuing forth wilfully with the urine, ſhews a vein to be broke in the bladder.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 79.
div.p: Sandy ſediments ſeething in the urine, argues the ſtone in the bladder.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 80.
div.p: He that piſſeth blood and matter like curdled milk with his urine, and if he hath a ſtrangury and the pain fall to the Perinaeum, and the lower belly, hath a Diſeaſe in thoſe parts which belong to the bladder.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 81.
div.p: He that piſſeth blood and corrupt matter, and ſmall scales with an ill odor in the urine, hath an ulcer in the bladder.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 82.
div.p: If a tumour grow in the conduit of the urine, if that ſuppurate, and break, a ſolution happens.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 83.
div.p: Very much urine made in the night, argues but few excrements by ſtool.

div.head: Sects. 5. Aph. 22.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſm in the Chapter of the affects of the Privities.]

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: The ſtrangury ſucceeds the inflamation of the the ſtreight inteſtine and the wombe, and ſuppurated reins, but the Hicket the inflamation of the liver.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 6.
div.p: The affects of the reins and the bladder, are not eaſily cured in old men.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 18.
div.p: If the bladder, brain, midriffe, or any thin bowel, ſtomach, or liver be cut into or divided, it is deadly.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 44.
div.p: The Iliack paſſion ſucceeding a Strangury, kils within ſeven dayes, unleſſe plenty of urine be made with a ſucceeding Feaver.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 32.
div.p: Urines with bilious ſediments but thin at the top, do ſignifie an acute Diſeaſe.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 34.
div.p: Urines with bubbles at the top, argue a Diſeaſe of the reins, and a long one too.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 35.
div.p: But when a fatneſſe is gathered together upon the top of the urine, it ſignifies an acute Diſeaſe of the reins.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 39.
div.p: [This Aphoriſm is the ſame with Sect. 4. Aph. 18. in this Chapter.]

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 48.
div.p: Drinking of wine and breathing a vein, doth take away the ſtrangury or difficulty of making water, but the inward veins muſt be opened.

div.head: Sect. 8. Aph. 11.
div.p: IF the right Teſticle be cold and convulſive, it is mortal.

div.head: CHAP. L. Of the affects of the Wombe.
Sect. 3. Aph. 12.
div.p: IF the wind be Southward in the winter, and the ſeaſon very wet, and the ſpring extraordinary dry, with North winds, women with Child which expect to be delivered in the ſpring, do abort upon any occaſion; and they which are delivered produce but weak and ſickly Infants, ſo that either they dye preſently, or if they live, are ſmall and ſickly, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 14.
div.p: A dry and cold Autumn with North winds, is commodious for thoſe who are of a moiſt conſtitution, and for women, &c.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 28.
div.p:
The Diſeaſes of Children, are uſually diſſolved
by their Criſis, ſome within forty dayes, ſome within ſeven months, and others within ſeven years, or about the time of fourteen years. But thoſe Diſeaſes which continue to children, and do not leave them at the age of fourteen, to Males, and to Females all the time of the eruption of their monthly purgations, uſually are of a long continuance.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 1.
div.p: Women with Child may be purged, if the humour incline of it ſelf to evacuation, in the fourth month unto the ſeventh, but in theſe leſs. But when the iſſue is newly conceived, or very big, we muſt be very wary and circumſpect.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 28.
div.p: Suffumigations of ſweet Odors, doth bring down the courſes in women, and were alſo profitable for other things, if they did not cauſe a heavineſſe in the head.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 30.
div.p: Phlebotomy or opening a vein, doth cauſe women with Child to abort, and then moſt certainly if the iſſue be very big.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 31.
div.p: If a woman with Child be taken with an acute Diſeaſe, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 34.
div.p: A Diarrhaea or flux of the belly, doth endanger abortion to great bellied women.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 45.
div.p:
If women of a rare texture or thin habit of body, do miſcarry or abort in the ſecond or third moneth, without a manifeſt occaſion, the veſſels of the wombe, called by the Greeks 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
▪ are full of corrupt matter, ſo that by reaſon of their fulneſſe and burthen, they cannot ſuſtain the Infant, but are burſt in ſunder.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 47.
div.p: If the wombe be ſuppurated in that part which extends it ſelf to, and reſteth upon the hip-bone, the cure muſt be wrought by Linements dipped in convenient Medicines.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 49.
div.p: Medicines cauſing ſneezing do expel the afterbirth, but after the taking of them, the Noſtrils and the mouth of the Patient muſt be cloſe ſtopped.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 51.
div.p: When women have conceived and are with Child, the Orifice of their wombe is contracted and ſhut cloſe.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 54.
div.p: If the Orifice of the wombe be hard and ſolid, it muſt of neceſſity be cloſe ſhut.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 55.
div.p:
If women with chiid fall into a feaver, and are emaciated or made lean without ſome maniſeſt cauſe, they have difficult and dangerous
travail, or elſe are in danger of abortion.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: A Strangury ſucceeds an inflamation of the ſtreight inteſtine of the wombe, or ſuppurated reins; but the Hicket an inflamation of the liver.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 62.
div.p: They which have cold and thick wombes, or elſe if their matrix be overmoiſt, do not conceive, for the genitive matter is extinguiſhed in them; neither they which have over dry and hot wombes, becauſe the ſeed is corrupted for want of nutriment. But they are moſt fruitful, which are of a middle and moderate conſtitution and temperature.

div.head: CHAP. LI. Of the Menſtruum, or Womens Purgations.
Sect. 5. Aph. 32.
div.p: VOmiting of blood is ſtayed by the breaking forth of the monthly purgations in women.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 33.
div.p: An Haemorrhagia or bleeding at the noſe, is beneficial to women in the deficiency of their monthly courſes.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 36.
div.p: Ill coloured purgations of women, and not proceeding alwayes at their appointed ſeaſons, ſignifie a neceſſity of purging.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 39.
div.p: It is an abſolute ſign of the deficiency or failing of her monthly purgations, if a woman who neither is with child, nor never brought forth child hath milk in her breaſts.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 50.
div.p: If you would ſtop the menſtruous flux in women, you muſt apply great Cupping-glaſſes to their breaſts.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 56.
div.p: A Convulſion happening to women in the time of her menſtruous purgations, is naught.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 57.
div.p: Both the overflowing of the monthly Terms, and the ſuppreſſion thereof, do cauſe Diſeaſes.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 60.
div.p: If a Woman with child have her courſes, it is impoſſible that her child ſhould be healthful.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 60.
div.p: If a woman have not her monthly purgations, and neither horror nor feaver ſucceed, but a nauſea or abhorring of meat happeneth unto her, believe her to have conceived with Child.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 29.
div.p: A woman is not troubled with the gout, until her monthly purgations have left her.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 41.
div.p: IF you would know whether a woman have conceived with child or not, give her water and hony mingled together when ſhe goeth to ſleep, and if ſhe have wringings and gripings of the belly, ſhe hath conceived, otherwiſe ſhe hath not.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 42.
div.p: If a woman be with child with a male, ſhe is better coloured than if ſhe were with child with a female.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 43.
div.p: An Eriſipilas in the wombe of a pregnant woman, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 46.
div.p: They which do not conceive by reaſon of a preternatural groſſeneſs, have the Orifice of their wombe preſſed by the Kell, neither will they be pregnant or conceive until they are extenuated or grown thinner.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 59.
div.p:
If a woman do not conceive, and you deſire to know whether ſhe be fruitful or wil conceive, apply ſuffumigations to her beneath, ſhe being
very well wrapt cloſe with Clothes; and if the ſent or ſmell be perceived to paſſe to her noſtrils and mouth, you may conclude her not to be unfruitful of her ſelf.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 61.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſme the laſt but one in the ſore-going Chapter of Womens monthly purgations.]

div.head: CHAP. LIII. Of Abortion or Miſcarriage.
Sect. 5. Aph. 30.
div.p: BReathing of a vein doth cauſe Abortion, but more eſpecially if the birth be ſomewhat big.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 37.
div.p: If the breaſts of a pregnant woman grow thin and ſlender on a ſuddain, there is danger of abortion.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 38.
div.p: If either of the breaſts of a pregnant woman with child with Twins, grow thin and ſlender, ſhe miſcarries with one of her burthens; if her right breaſt grow thin, ſhe aborts a male, if the left, a female child.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 44.
div.p: Women which are made lean by ſome preternatural cauſe, do abort until they grow more full bodied.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 45.
div.p: They which abort the ſecond or third month, without ſome eſpecial occaſion, have the veſſels of their wombe filled with filthy matter, ſo that by reaſon of that burthen they do break, and cannot contain the iſſue.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 55.
div.p: If pregnant women fall into a feaver, and are very much waſted without ſome ſenſible cauſe, either have difficult and dangerous labour, or elſe fall into a hazard of abortion.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 7.
div.p: A Tenaſmus, or a frequent and vain deſire of going to ſtool without any performance, coming upon a pregnant women, doth make her abort.

div.head: CHAP. LIII. Of the Iſſue and the Birth.
Sect. 5. Aph. 35.
div.p: SNeezing happening to one troubled with the ſuffocation of the Matrix, or elſe to one in hard travail, is commodious.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 48.
div.p: Male Children are born in the right, and females in the left ſide of the wombe.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 52.
div.p: Store of milk flowing forth of the breaſts of a woman with child, ſignifies a weak child, but ſolid and firm breaſts argue a ſtronger and more healthful child.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 53.
div.p: When the child is like to dye in the wombe, the breaſts of the mother grow ſlender, but if they become hard, ſhe will have grief either in her breaſts, her hips, in her eyes or knees, and ſhe will not corrupt her iſſue.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 55.
div.p: Feavers and extreme waſtings happening to women with child, argue either a difficult and dangerous travail to them, or a hazard of abortion.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 6.
div.p: It is impoſſible that that child ſhould be healthful which is bread by one who hath her monthly courſes in the time of her Childbearing.

div.head: CHAP. LIV. Of the affects of the Joints.
Sect. 2. Aph. 46.
div.p: WHen two pains are felt at one and the ſame time in different places of the body, the one doth very much obſcure the other.

div.head: Sect. 1. Aph. 16.
div.p: Great droughts cauſe conſumptions, ſore eyes, pains of the joynts, difficulty of Urine, and excoriations of the bowels.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: In the ſpring ſeaſon, madneſs, melancholly, the falling evil, fluxes of blood, ſquinances, rheums, hoarſeneſs, coughs, leproſies, tetters, dry itches, ulcerous pimples, ſmall ſwellings, and pains of the joynts do afflict mens bodies.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 31.
div.p: Difficulty of breathing, catarrhes, ſtranguries, difficulty of making water, pains of the joynts and reins, vertigoes, and apoplexies are incident to old men.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 20.
div.p: Extreme gripings and twiſtings of the bowels, heavineſs of the knees, and a pain of the loins without a feaver, tell us that purging downward is neceſſary.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 31.
div.p: When a ſenſe of wearyiſhneſs occaſioned by Feavers, is preſent, then tumours do ariſe about the joynts, but eſpecially about the mandibles.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 32.
div.p: But if any part be full of pain after the recovering from a Diſeaſe, the abſceſſes are made to that part.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 44.
div.p: Small tumours and pains of the joynts do appear to ſuch who have had long feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 45.
div.p: They who have tumours, and pains about their joynts after long Feavers, do feed more plentifully.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 74.
div.p: When there is a probability that ſome matter will be ſent to the joynts, plenty of urine and white being made, doth deliver from the abſceſs. Such as uſually begin to be conveyed every 4th, day in feavers with a wearyiſh indiſpoſition; and if a flux of blood break forth by the Noſtrils alſo, then the ſolution of the Diſeaſe will be very ſhortly.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 25.
div.p:
Plenty of cold water caſt upon the tumours of the joynts, griefs without ulcers, the places affected with the gout and convulſive members,
for the moſt part eaſeth them, diminiſheth and takes away the grief; for a moderate numneſſe hath a property to take away pain.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 28.
div.p: Eunuches are not afflicted with the gout, neither do they grow bald.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 29.
div.p: A woman is not troubled with the gout, before her monthly purgations ceaſe.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 30.
div.p: A boy is not troubled with the gout before he uſe the act of Venery.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 49.
div.p: The gout Diſeaſes do ſtop within forty dayes, the inflamation being taken away.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 55.
div.p: The affects of the gout uſually expreſſe themſelves in the Spring and Autumn.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 59.
div.p: In Sciatick pains when the hip bone falls out of his place, and is received again, filthy matter is ingendred therein.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 60.
div.p: They which are troubled with a continual Sciatica, if the head of the hip bone fall out of its place, have their thigh waſted, and they halt unleſſe they are cured by cauterizing.

div.head: CHAP. LV. Of the affects of the Fingers and Nails.
Sect. 8. Aph. 12.
div.p: IF the nails grow black, and the fingers and toes either contracted or remiſſe, argue death approching.

div.head: Diſtinction the ſeventh, containing ſuch Aphoriſmes which reſpect external Diſeaſes of the body.

p.hi: THe Phyſician which deſires to be complete and abſolute in his practice, muſt not only have the knowledge of thoſe Aphoriſmes which reſpect the internal Diſeaſes of the body, but muſt alſo have thoſe Aphoriſmes in his memory which do treat of external Diſeaſes, and they are theſe which follow.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Affects of the Hair.
Sect. 5. Aph. 11.
div.p: IF the Spittle of conſumptive perſons being caſt upon the coals ſend forth an ill ſmell, and if the hairs of the head fall away, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 28.
div.p: Eunuchs neither have the gout nor grow bald.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 34.
div.p: They which are bald have not their veins ſwelled with melancholly blood, but they to whom ſuch ſwellings ſo happen being bald, have the hair of their head grow again.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: IN the ſpring ſeaſon, madneſs, melancholly, the falling evil, fluxes of blood, ſquinancies, rheums, hoarſeneſs, coughs, leproſies, tetters, the dry itch, very many ulcerated pimples, ſmall tumours, and pains of the joynts, do ariſe.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 9.
div.p: Broad wheals do ſeldome itch.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 34.
div.p: IF a ſuddain ſtrangulation ſeize him which hath a Feaver without a praeexiſtent feaver in the jawes, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 35.
div.p: If the neck of one that hath a feaver be on the ſudden perverted and turned, ſo that he can ſcarce or hardly ſwallow, without a conſpicuous humour, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 25.
div.p: Abundance of cold water caſt thereon, eaſeth, diminiſheth, and takes away the pains of tumified and painful places without ulcers, the affects of the gout, and of convulſed Members; for a moderate ſtupefaction hath a power to take away grief.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 65.
div.p: They which have ulcerous tumours conſpicuous, are neither convulſive, nor mad; but they preſently vaniſhing; if the abſceſs be backward, they are taken with convulſions and cramps; but if the abſceſs happen to the foreparts, they are troubled with ragings, acute Diſeaſes of the ſides and ſuppuration of humours, if the tumours be red.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 66.
div.p: It is a very great miſchief when no tumor is ſeen acompanying great and ſhrewd wounds.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 67.
div.p: Soft tumours are good, crude naught.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 37.
div.p: A tumour ariſing in the neck of him which hath a ſquinancy, is a good ſign, for then the Diſeaſe is thruſt outward.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 49.
div.p: A ſwelling or tumour appearing in the breaſt of him which is ſick of a ſquinancy, is a good ſigne, for then the morbifick matter is ſecured to the external parts.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 23.
div.p: THeſe Diſeaſes are common to Infants, creeping ulcers of the mouth called Apthae, vomitings, coughs, watchings, tremblings, inflamations about the navil, and moiſtneſs of the ears.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 23.
div.p:
We muſt make uſe of cold things in theſe caſes, when either there is a preſent flux of blood, or when one will preſently enſue, but they muſt
not be applyed upon but about the place from whence the flux is, and if an inflamation or fierineſſe incline to a ſomewhat bloody or red colour, cauſed by a flux of freſh blood, appear, apply them thereunto, for they cauſe blackneſſe to inveterate ſores. They help an Eriſipilas not ulcerated, but offend an ulcerated.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 58.
div.p: A ſtrangury ſucceeds an inflamation of the ſtreight bowel of the wombe and ſuppurated reins; but the Hicket ſucceeds an inflamation of the liver.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 40.
div.p: A ſucceeding feaver takes away ſuch pains which ariſe about the midriffe, which are not accompanyed with an inflamation.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 23.
div.p: SEE this Aphoriſme in the preceeding Chapter of Inflamation.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 43.
div.p: An Eriſipilas happening in the wombe of a pregnant woman, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 25.
div.p:
It is a bad Symptome if an Eriſipilas being
