once thruſt forth turn back to the inward parts, but if it come to the external from the internal parts, it is good.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 19.
div.p: An Eriſipilas is cauſed by the laying bare of a bone.
Rottenneſſe, or impoſtumation cauſed by an Eriſipilas, is bad.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Mortification and a Gangrena.
Sect. 7. Aph. 2.
div.p: Wan and pale fleſh occaſioned by a pained bone, doth ſignifie ill.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 50.
div.p: If the brain be ſuddenly ſtrucken or mortified the ſick dyes within three dayes, the which if he ſurvive, he becomes ſound again.
A bone decayes by mortification or a gangrene.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 38.
div.p: IT is more ſafe not to cure then to cure hidden and ſecret Cancers, for if they are cured, the ſick dyes quickly, but if left uncured he continue • longer.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 22.
div.p: SEE this Aphoriſme in Sect. 5. Aph. 22. in the Chapter of Convulſions.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the tumour called Struma.
Sect. 3. Aph. 26.
div.p: BUt when they are a little more in years, inflamations of the Almonds of the ears, impulſions toward the inward part of the vertebra in the hinder part of the head, frequent Aſthmaes, the ſtone, maw-worms, round-worms, and others thin and ſmall, breeding in the ſtreight gut, ſwellings in the neck, and other ſmall tumours, but eſpecially theſe.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Impoſtumes about the Privy parts.
Sect. 4. Aph. 55.
div.p: ALL Feavers coming of an inflamation of the glandulous parts are bad, but Ephemeraes.

div.head: Sect. 2. Aph. 15.
div.p: WHen pains in the jaws, or ſmall tumours ariſe in the body, the excrements muſt be obſerved, for if they are cholerick, the body is alſo ſick, but if ſuch are voided as come from healthful bodies, you may nouriſh the body without danger.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſme in the Chapter of the Affects of the joynts.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 26.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſme in the third Chapter of the fourth Diſtinction, in the Chapter of Diſeaſes incident to Children.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 44.
div.p: Small tumours and pains in the joynts, do ſucceed long feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 45.
div.p: They feed liberally who have ſmall ſwellings or pains in their joynts ariſing after long feavers.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 82.
div.p: If a ſmall ſwelling ariſe in the conduit of the urine, when that is ſuppurated and broke, a ſolution happens.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 8.
div.p: Faintings, vomitings and ſwoundings are contingent, by the breach of an impoſtumation inwardly.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 57.
div.p: [You have this Aphoriſme verbatim in this Chapter, Aph. 82.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the ſwelling of the veins by melancholly blood called verrucae.
Sect. 3. Aph. 26.
div.p: I Refer the reader for this Aphoriſme, to the Chapter of the Diſeaſes of Children, where he may be ſatisfied.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 2.
div.p: A Convulſion chancing ſuddenly upon a wound, is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 18.
div.p: If the Bladder be cut or wounded, the brain, heart, midriffe, or any thin bowel, either ſtomach or liver, it is mortal.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 66.
div.p: If no tumour appear in great and naughty wounds, it is a very great miſcheif.

div.head: Sect. 6. Aph. 19.
div.p: A bone wounded or cut, a griſſel, nerve, or any ſmall particle of the mandible, the foreskin of the yard called the praeputium, doth neither encreaſe nor grow together again.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of Abſceſſes or Impoſtumations.
Sect. 4. Aph. 31.
div.p: WHen there is a weariſhneſs or indiſpoſition of the body occaſioned by long feavers, an abſceſs or impoſtumation will ariſe about the joynts, but eſpecially about the mandibles.

div.head: Sect. 7. Aph. 36.
div.p: When in the pains of the reins beſides other ſymptomes there are pains felt about the muſcles of the back bone, becauſe the matter is carried outward, we muſt expect the impoſtumation outward. But if the pains tend more to the internal parts, it is to be feared that the impoſtumation will be rather inward.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 20.
div.p: SEE this Aphoriſme in the Chapter of Hoarſeneſs and coughs in the fifth Diſtinction.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 22.
div.p: [See this Aphoriſm in the Chapter of Autumnal Diſeaſes in the fourth Diſtinction.

div.head: Sect. 3. Aph. 24.
div.p: Moreover theſe Diſeaſes happen to Children, creeping ulcers of the mouth, vomitings, coughs watchings, tremblings, inflamations about the navil, and moiſture of their ears.

div.head: Sect. 4. Aph. 75.
div.p: Blood or ſuppurated matter voided with the urine, doth ſignifie an exulceration of the reins and bladder.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 20.
div.p: Cold corodes ulcers, obdures the skin, hinders ſuppuration, cauſeth blackneſs, rigors in feavers, convulſions, and cramps.

div.head: Sect. 5. Aph. 21.
div.p: Yet ſometimes in a diſtenſion of the nerves without an ulcer, to young and well proportion'd bodies in the middle of Summer, a pouring on of cold water doth cauſe a Revocation of heat, but heat muſt cure theſe diſtemperatures.

div.head: Books ſold by R. Crofts at the Crown in Chancery-Lane, where you may have all ſorts of Playes.
div.p: OFficium Quotidianum: or a Manual of private Devotions. By the moſt Reverend Father in God Dr. William Laud late Lord Arch-Biſhop of Canterbury.

The Young Clerks Tutor; being a moſt uſeful Collection of the beſt Preſidents of Recognizances, Obligations, Conditions, Acquittances, Bills of Sale, Warrants of Attorney, &c. As alſo all the Names of Men and Women in Latin; with the day of the Date, the ſeveral Sums of Money, and the Addition of the ſeveral Trades or Employments in their proper Caſes, as they ſtand in the Obligations. Together with Directions of Writs of Habeas Corpus, Writs of Error, &c. to the inferiour Courts in Cities and Towns; the whole Work newly corrected and augmented. Likewiſe the beſt Preſidents of all manner of Concords, of Fines, and Directions how to ſue out a Fine; with many judicious Obſervations therein. There is alſo added ſeveral of the beſt Copies both of Court and Chancery Hands now extant; by Edward Cocker.
The Young Clerk's Copy-Book: Containing the beſt Preſidents for Court and Chancery Hands extant. And all other Hands proper to Clerkship. By Edward Cocker.
Old Law, a Comedy. Marriage Night, a Comedy. Polititian Cheated a Comedy. Spaniſh Gipſies, a Comedy. Careleſſe Shepherdeſſe. Loves Miſtriſs. Fathers own Son. Dutcheſſe of Malfy, &c.
